paper_abstract: We consider the problem of planar spanning tree transformation in a two-dimensional plane. Given two planar trees T(1) and T(2) drawn oil a set S of n points in general position in the plane, the problem is to transform T(1) into T(2) by a sequence of simple changes called edge-flips or just flips. A flip is an operation by which one edge e of a geometric object is removed and an edge f (f not equal e) is inserted such that the resulting object belongs to the same class as the original object. We present two algorithms for planar tree transformations. The first technique is an indirect approach which relies oil some 'canonical' tree to obtain such transformation results. It is shown that it takes at most 2n - m - s - 2 flips (m, s > 0) which is an improvement over the result in [D. Avis, K. Fukuda, Reverse search for enumeration, Discrete Applied Mathematics 65 (1996) 21-46]. Second, we present a direct approach which takes at most n - 1 + k flips (k >= 0) for Such transformation when S in convex position and also show results when the points are in general position. We provide cases where the second technique performs an optimal number of flips. A counterexample is given to show that if vertical bar T(1) \ T(2)vertical bar = k then they cannot be transformed to one another by k flips. (C) 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Planar tree transformation: Results and counterexample
